title: 115_hr257
content: The Act may be cited as the "Recognition of Jerusalem as the Capital of the State of Israel Act". Congress acknowledges the historical connection of the Jewish people to Israel and Jerusalem, the establishment of the State of Israel in 1948 as a homeland for Jews, the reunification of Jerusalem in 1967, and the disputed sovereignty claims over certain areas by Jordan. In 1990, Congress adopted Senate Concurrent Resolution 106, declaring Jerusalem must remain undivided with rights protected. In 1995, Congress approved the Jerusalem Embassy Act, requiring the US Embassy in Jerusalem by May 31, 1999. Israel has exceeded Hague Regulation, ensuring public order in Jerusalem. Civil life thrives under Israel's administration. Under Israel's administration, civil life thrives in Jerusalem with all government institutions present, including the Knesset, Bank of Israel, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Prime Minister's and President's offices, and the Supreme Court. Recognition of Jerusalem as the capital of Israel and relocation of the US embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem. The United States policy recognizes Jerusalem as the undivided capital of Israel, and Congress supports this by affirming the need to relocate the US Embassy to Jerusalem. The United States recognizes Jerusalem as the undivided capital of Israel and supports relocating the US Embassy there by January 1, 2019. Jerusalem must be identified as the capital of Israel on all official US Government documents. United States officials should comply with US law on this matter. The Jerusalem Embassy Act of 1995 is amended by repealing section 7 and redesignating section 8 as section 7. The repeal will take effect on January 1, 2018. Additionally, there will be an implementation report required. The Secretary of State must submit a report to Congress within 30 days of the Act's enactment detailing the plan to establish the US Embassy in Jerusalem, including estimated completion dates and funding requirements.
